score all right let's talk about fine tuning model interpretation because this is super important this is a part of
what uh of the skill set that data scientists traditionally brought to the table imagine we have a binary
classification model here that attempts to answer the question of is this email
spam or not so of course we want a model that makes as few mistakes as possible
but beyond that we can note that different mistakes have different costs a model like this can make two
kinds of mistakes it can create a false positive where an email that is legitimate gets marked as spam and put
into the spam folder or it can create a false negative where a spam email actually sneaks through and appears in
the inbox when you think about these these two mistakes have very different costs the cost of false negative is um
in many cases annoyance I look at a spam email I know it's spam I delete it the cost of a false positive is a
potentially very important legitimate email going into my spam folder and getting Auto deleted from it after 30
days and I'll never see it again this could be disastrous and so we can actually take
this knowledge and use it to inform the interpretation of our machine learning model in this case I'm going to grab
this slider in the middle and drag it to the right to indicate um to
that I want my false positive rate to be much lower than it is now at
2.4% and what that does is it affects a special number called the cutof threshold essentially when a model makes
a prediction it gives us a score between zero and one which is the likelihood of
this observation of this data record being positive in our case spam so right
now this threshold is 0.5 you can see it in the upper right corner by moving it up to
0.81 I can now I've now made a deliberate balance that I want very few false positives now I only have half a
percent false positives in my valuation sample at this threshold and now I can save this
threshold and it will be applied to the predictions I generate this is a fantastic way to connect the machine
learning models to the business requirements around them and in just a second I'll show you how the threshold
actually gets used because we're about to get to the third stage which is retrieving predictions
there are two ways to get predictions in Amazon machine learning batch and in real time batch predictions are used for
asynchronous large volume prediction generation whenever you have a data system which itself operates on batches
of data you may have a system that receives new data records they're imported in database perhaps on daily
basis and you want to you want to get predictions for all of these data records at once batch predictions
interface is the right match for that uh the batch prediction interface can be used through either the console or the
API um I won't put you through the console wizard because it looks very similar to the Wizards we've already

called create batch prediction we put in a batch prediction ID that is the ID of the request that we are about to create

points to the data for which we want to create batch predictions we put in the ID of the model that is used to generate
the batch predictions and lastly we enter the URI where we want the predictions to be
output and the output looks like this the output will be out will be in S3 in
one or more CS3 files and it has two columns there is a column named best
answer and there is column named score the score is the actual prediction score for this data record and these data
these can be merged back with the original data records one by one and the best answer is what's obtained by
comparing that score against the threshold that we've established earlier this allows this transfer of Knowledge
from the person who is building the model to the person who is building the
system that consumes predictions eliminating any chance for a gap along the way next let's let's talk about
